Dear Amanda Waidelich:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM, and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was swinging at a staff member and grabbing at their hair.
Another staff member approached to assist in getting the youth to
release the staff's hair and observed that the staff member also
had ahold of the youth's hair. The staff member appeared
agitated.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/25/25.
Youth A reported he was in the cafeteria, but he couldn’t
remember why. Youth A reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 were in the
cafeteria with him. Youth A reported Staff 2 poked him in the eye
when they were in the cafeteria. Youth A reported he pulled Staff
2’s hair 5 different times and Staff 1 helped release his hands from
Staff 2’s hair. Youth A reported one time, Staff 2 grabbed his hair
and Staff 1 pushed Staff 2 off to get her to stop. Youth A did not
want to be asked any other questions and ended the interview
quickly.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/25/25.
Staff 1 reported as soon as she and Staff 2 brought Youth A into
the cafeteria, Youth A immediately began running and going after
Staff 2. Staff 1 reported Youth A began pulling Staff 2’s hair, so
Staff 1 completed an approved grip release. Staff 1 reported
Youth A began slamming his body into the cafeteria door trying to
get it open. Staff 1 reported she was trying to verbally de-escalate
Youth A by talking to him and offering him different options. Youth
A began running and punching at things in the cafeteria. Staff 1
reported at one point, he went to punch Staff 2, Staff 2 blocked
Youth A’s punch. Staff 1 reported after the block, Youth A flung his
hand backwards and began screaming about his eye. Staff 1
reported Staff 2 never hit Youth A in the eye, and it was Youth A’s
own hand which hit him. Staff 1 reported Youth A grabbed Staff
2’s hair again. Staff 1 reported she completed an approved grip
release, but when she did it, she realized Staff 2 also had her
hand on Youth A’s hair. Staff 1 reported she wasn’t sure if Staff 2
even realized she had a hold of Youth A’s hair because she didn’t
2

acknowledge it at all. Staff 1 reported she did an approved grip
release to get Staff 2’s hand off Youth A’s hair, and Staff 1 didn’t
acknowledge the grip release either. Staff 1 reported she
completed some deep breaths and counted with Youth A to de-
escalate him. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 asked Youth A a question
(couldn’t remember what), and Youth A escalated again. Staff 1
reported Youth A got up, and while he was moving around, he
tripped, fell and hit himself in the eye. Staff 1 reported Youth A got
up, began running after Staff 2 and began attacking her again.
Staff 1 reported she had to do a restraint on Youth A for safety of
Staff 2. Staff 1 reported once Youth A calmed down, he was given
a bag of ice and cold washcloth for his eye as well as a snack.
Staff 1 reported Staff 4, Staff 5 and Supervisor came into the
cafeteria at different points to ask if they needed a break. Staff 1
reported she was fine with Youth A, so she did not swap out. Staff
1 reported Staff 2 refused to swap out and stated she didn’t need
to.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/25/25.
Staff 2 reported Youth A grabbed her hair several times while they
were in the cafeteria, so she had to grab her hair at a higher point
to prevent him from pulling (i.e. he was pulling the ends of her
hair, and she was grabbing the hair closer to her roots to prevent
him from pulling it). Staff 2 reported she never grabbed Youth A’s
hair because he has no hair to grab. Staff 2 reported the only thing
she grabbed the whole time was his legs, which was to help Staff
1 out when Staff 1 had Youth A in a restraint. Staff 2 reported
Youth A was flailing his legs everywhere and Staff 1 was having a
hard time keeping a hold of him. Staff 2 couldn’t remember what
Youth A or Staff 1’s body positions were during the restraint. Staff
2 reported at one point, Youth A tried to punch her, and when she
blocked him, the back of her hand slid down his face. Staff 2
reported Youth A began screaming and started digging in his eye.
Staff 2 reported Staff 1 began talking to Youth A about getting a
snack to calm him down. Staff 2 reported she was not frustrated
during any part of this situation, and felt she was completely calm.
Staff 2 reported she never said Youth A fell on the floor or
punched himself in the face.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 5/7/25. Staff 3 reported he
was on B-side in the hallway, monitoring youth who were in their
rooms. Staff 3 reported he did not witness Staff 1 and Staff 2’s
interactions with Youth A while they were in the cafeteria.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/25/25.
Staff 4 reported she was in the B-side milieu. Staff 4 reported she
3

opened the cafeteria to check on Staff 1, Staff 2 and Youth A.
Staff 4 reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 were starting an approved PRT
restraint on Youth A with Youth A sitting on the ground. Staff 4
reported Staff 2 was trying to get behind Youth A in the PRT
position and Staff 1 was holding Youth A’s legs. Staff 4 reported
Youth A was trying to grab Staff 2’s hair. Staff 4 reported Youth A
was trying to rotate his body, so Staff 4 reminded Staff 1 and Staff
2 they could not restrain Youth A if he turned onto his stomach.
Staff 4 reported Youth B began yelling and getting frustrated, so
she shut the cafeteria door so she could focus on calming Youth B
down.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 4/30/25. Staff 5 reported
whenever Youth A is in the cafeteria, he always screams. Staff 5
reported hearing Youth A screaming, so she went to check on
him, Staff 1 and Staff 2. Staff 5 reported she saw Youth A was just
screaming, and nothing else was happening, so she shut the door.
Staff 5 reported hearing Youth A screaming again, so she opened
the door again. Staff 5 reported Youth A had a hold of Staff 2’s
hair and Staff 2 was doing an approved grip release. Staff 5
reported Staff 1 was trying to restrain Youth A as Staff 2 was
trying to do the grip release. Staff 5 reported Staff 1 and Staff 2
were doing the grip release and restraint appropriately. Staff 5
reported she walked into the cafeteria and asked if Staff 1 or Staff
2 needed anything. Staff 5 reported Staff 1 was trying to get Staff
2 to take a break because Youth A was targeting Staff 2, but Staff
2 refused and said she didn’t need a break. Staff 5 reported she
asked Staff 2 if she wanted to swap out, but Staff 2 refused. Staff
5 reported Youth A said his eyes were burning, so Staff 1 asked
Staff 2 to grab a wet washcloth and a glass of water. Staff 5
reported she wiped Youth A’s eyes and face with the wet towel,
and then she left after he calmed down a bit. Staff 5 reported Staff
1 and Staff 2 did nothing wrong or inappropriate while she was in
the cafeteria.
Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 5/5/25. Supervisor
reported he went into the cafeteria to check on Youth A, Staff 1
and Staff 2. Supervisor reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 were in
opposite spaces and were not next to Youth A when he walked in.
Supervisor reported Staff 2 asked Supervisor to sit in the cafeteria
for a little bit in case something happened. Supervisor reported
Youth A was hitting the walls and guardrail which divides the
kitchen from the cafeteria. Supervisor reported he was in the
cafeteria for about 5 minutes but then he left because they were
doing fine. Supervisor reported he did not see anything
concerning while he was present.
4

Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 4/25/25. CA reported Staff 2 has never been part of
physical management before. CA reported Staff 2 normally takes
other youth to another room while other staff handle the crisis. CA
reported she was in a restraint refresher training with Staff 2 and
Staff 2 seemed hesitant. CA reported she had the restraint trainer
meet with Staff 2 individually to address Staff 2’s concerns so she
could feel more confident. CA reported after Staff 2 and the trainer
met, the trainer said Staff 2 was good to go.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Agency response strategy dated 4/22/25 states Staff 2 will
be off the schedule and away from Youth A pending
investigation.
• Discipline Policy states the facility prohibits all cruel and
severe discipline, including any type of corporal punishment
inflicted in any manner.
• Incident Report authored by Staff 1 dated 4/22/25 states
after entering the cafeteria, Youth A ran towards Staff 2
with a closed fist, and Staff 2 used HWC approved blocks.
Youth A found some cooked carrots on the ground and
threw them at Staff 2. Youth A grabbed Staff 2’s hair, and
Staff 1 completed a HWC approved grip release. Youth A
began to run into the cafeteria door with his body. Youth A
ran into the door twice and then headbutted the cafeteria
gate. Youth A ran up to Staff 2 and pulled her hair. Staff 1
completed an HWC approved grip release. Staff 1 also had
to release Staff 2’s hand from Youth A’s hair. Youth A
grabbed Staff 1 and Staff 2’s hair. Staff 1 did a hair release
while calling for additional staff. Youth A released their hair,
ran to a table to take a seat and breathe. Staff 1 started to
count to ten while doing yoga stretches to help Youth A
calm down. Youth A took deep breaths and Staff 2 asked if
Youth A was calm enough for a snack. Youth A ran across
the cafeteria with a closed fist, slipped, and punched
himself in the eye as he fell. Youth A got up and yelled his
eye was “burning” while he swatted at Staff 2. Staff 1 asked
Youth A to take a seat so his eye could be looked at. Staff
1 offered Youth A a bag of ice if he could show he could be
safe enough with it. Youth A began to scream, ran towards
Staff 2 and pulled her hair again. Staff 1 completed another
grip release and Youth A ran to the other side of the
cafeteria. Youth A was asked to take some deep breaths so
5

he could get a snack and a bag of ice. Youth A ran and
started to hit Staff 2. Staff 1 initiated a HWC approved PRT
and Youth A attempted to bite Staff 1 and Staff 2’s legs.
Staff 2 held Youth A’s legs while Staff 1 held Youth A’s
arms. Staff 1 started deep breaths and quiet counting to
help Youth A focus on his breathing. Youth A stated he was
hot and sweaty and needed to take off his sweatshirt. Staff
1 told A once he was calm, he could be released. Youth A
completed deep breaths and then was released. Youth A
took a seat at the table while Staff 2 got Youth A a cold, wet
washcloth and some tissues. Staff 1 placed the washcloth
on Youth A’s eyes and grabbed him a snack. Once calm,
he left the cafeteria with Staff 1 and Staff 2.
• Staff 2 does not have any disciplinary records in her
employee file. Staff 2 completed HWC training on 10/26/23,
10/27/23, 4/4/24, 9/18/24, and 2/6/25.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as per interviews conducted, Staff
1 and Youth A reported Staff 2 grabbed Youth A’s hair. Staff 2
reported Youth A did not have enough hair to grab, but Consultant
interviewed Youth A face to face and confirmed that was untrue.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility should ensure staff are trained to swap out with other
staff if they are being targeted by youth. In this situation, many
offers were made to swap out and Staff 2 refused despite being
targeted by Youth A repeatedly. Swapping out may have de-
escalated the situation faster.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR#2024C0001020 approved 1/18/24; CAP approved 2/9/24
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth's behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth's
treatment plan.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation On 4/21/25, a youth was inappropriately escorted to a safe space
due to exhibiting behaviors.
6

Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/25/25.
Youth A reported he could not remember how he got from B-side
into the cafeteria or why he went into the cafeteria.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/25/25.
Staff 1 reported Youth A was escalated on B-side due to a peer
conflict. Staff 1 reported she and Staff 2 were trying to separate
Youth A from the conflict, so they escorted Youth A to the
cafeteria. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 had her hips on the door and
Staff 2 was behind Youth A holding his arms as they were going
through the door. Staff 1 reported she was helping with the door
and blocking the door from Youth A’s feet. Staff 1 reported Youth
A was resisting as they were bringing him into the cafeteria. Staff
1 reported Youth A tried to drop weight and Staff 2 held Youth A’s
arms a little harder and tried getting him through the door. Staff 1
reported it was an improper escort. Staff 1 reported at no point did
she or Staff 2 pick Youth A up off the floor to get him into the
cafeteria.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/25/25.
Staff 2 reported Youth A was escalated on B-side and was trying
to throw kicks and punches towards the other kids on the unit.
Staff 2 reported Staff 1 blocked Youth A’s punches and kicks, so
he did not make contact with other youth. Staff 2 reported Staff 1
asked Youth A to go to the cafeteria and Youth A screamed, “No!”.
Staff 2 reported Staff 1 asked Youth A again, but Youth A began
running around the room trying to hit, kick, and punch whoever
was nearby. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 got Youth A into a hold of
some sort, but she couldn’t describe what it looked like. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 was trying to get Youth A into the cafeteria, but
she wasn’t getting very far. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 had Youth A
from behind, so Staff 2 picked him up by the legs because he
wasn’t moving. Staff 2 reported they carried Youth A into the
cafeteria and Youth A was screaming his pants were coming
down. Staff 2 reported they put him down and let him go once they
were in the cafeteria.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 5/7/25. Staff 3 reported he
was on B-side in the hallway, monitoring youth who were in their
rooms. Staff 3 reported he did not witness Staff 1 and Staff 2
getting Youth A into the cafeteria.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/25/25.
Staff 4 reported Youth A was escalated due to a peer conflict with
Youth B. Staff 4 reported she was blocking Youth B and Staff 1
7

and Staff 2 were blocking Youth A. Staff 4 reported she took
Youth B to another part of the milieu to get away from the
situation. Staff 4 reported she heard the cafeteria door open, but
did not see Staff 1 or Staff 2 get Youth A into the cafeteria.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 4/30/25. Staff 5 reported
she was not present when Staff 1 and Staff 2 brought Youth A into
the cafeteria and did not see how they got him there.
Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 5/5/25. Supervisor
reported he was not present when Staff 1 and Staff 2 brought
Youth A into the cafeteria and did not see how they got him there.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 4/25/25. CA reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 originally
stated they escorted Youth A to the cafeteria. However, CA now
knows based on Staff 1 and Staff 2’s descriptions of the incident, it
was a restraint since both staff admitted Youth A did not want to
go to the cafeteria. CA reported staff should never pick up a youth
to bring them to another room.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Youth A’s Individual Safety and Calming Plan goes over
Youth A’s triggers, counterproductive strategies not to use,
precursors to aggression, calming strategies & coping
skills, pro-active strategies, crisis intervention strategies,
and emergency safety/last resorts. One crisis intervention
strategy is to allow space/time away from other peers by
utilizing the cafeteria or his room.
• Incident Report authored by Staff 1 dated 4/22/25 states
Youth A attempted to bite a peer’s leg. Staff 4 blocked the
bite using an HWC approved block. Staff 3 and Staff 2 used
their bodies to separate Youth A from his peers. After
exhausting all calm down techniques and strategies, Staff 1
and Staff 2 escorted Youth A to the cafeteria.
• HWC manual shows an approved two-person escort
technique, which is when two staff stand on either side of a
youth while one hand is holding onto the youth’s wrist and
the other hand is placed palm-up on the youth’s back. This
is not the escort technique described by Staff 1 or Staff 2.
• Restraint Policy states the emergency physical intervention
should not be used if it is not in compliance with techniques
approved by Hope Network Behavioral Health Services and
8

any responsible mental health agency or is not in
compliance with the emergency interventions authorized in
the youth’s individual plan or treatment plan. Restraints
shall not be used for staff convenience.
• Staff 1 does not have any disciplinary records in her
employee file. Staff 1 completed HWC training on 1/20/25
and 1/21/25.
• Staff 2 does not have any disciplinary records in her
employee file. Staff 2 completed HWC training on 10/26/23,
10/27/23, 4/4/24, 9/18/24, and 2/6/25.
Analysis The facility is found in violation based on interviews conducted.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were not consistent regarding the details of
how they got Youth A from B-side to the cafeteria, Youth A could
not remember how he got into the cafeteria, and no one else
witnessed the situation. However, it is clear from both Staff 1 and
Staff 2’s interviews, the way they got him there was not done
appropriately. Whether they picked Youth A up and brought him
into the cafeteria, or they held onto his arms and brought him in
there while he was resistant, neither one is an appropriate or
approved escort. Since Youth A was resistant, either method falls
under the definition of a personal restraint, and neither method is
an approved restraint technique.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
An email was sent to the facility on 3/14/25 explaining the
difference between an escort and a restraint. This was also
discussed with leadership during an on-site visit at the facility for
their interim audit on 4/4/25.
Conclusion Violation Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
